channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: No bookstore patron thinks very long about praise written in blurb-speak.
Clever comments are a waste of breath, of which we have finite supply.

While browsing in the campus bookstore once, back in the years when those words meant something, I looked up and saw one of the elder faculty poets rearranging a shelf of volumes so not the very slender spine but the arty front cover of his own book faced out.
“Great poetry lives in a state of perpetual transformation, perpetual translation: the poem dies when it has no place to go.” —Eliot Weinberger, Nineteen Ways of Looking at Wang Wei

I don't mean to idealize the past, since people with a good memory can easily recall no shortage of abominable behavior, but there have been groups of people who have tried to share responsibility for disseminating worthy information online.
Fifteen or twenty years ago it was commonly understood that a community of bloggers with a shared interest acted like a team of information screeners. When something was published that mattered to fans of their shared topic, someone in the group would notice.
Having noticed, one or more people would skim or read well, comment shallowly or thoughtfully, add a link, and spread the word in the community. If the thing was really promising, a second wave of readers would build on the early notices with further thoughts of their own.
There would be arguments of fact and interpretation, and the new item would begin to enter the tested and perhaps taken-for-granted contents of the community's hive mind. It might be improved in the process.
Being the blogosphere, traces of the shared work would make their way down the many screens into archives, becoming less useful there as days went by. Some people would have been informed and perhaps energized. Maybe they'd try something new out in the world. Or maybe not.
@AndySylvester99 It’s this assemblage on Twitter. https://t.co/b8Tsb6plQF
@AndySylvester99 @davewiner I see that Politico has a list with about 30 writers on Ukraine developments.

Just crept above 32 degrees here in northern Indiana. Our older neighbor with the big, skinny, long-haired dog ambled by in his winter coat, yellow whiffle ball bat in hand in case any off-leash pups approach. It’s a long story.

@davewiner I won’t argue, but maybe just think aloud for a further moment. I don’t know if people are using the lists feature enough to make it very meaningful for spreading political awareness. How to show people the value of a tool inside Twitter or outside? Still musing…
Decades of activism work remind folks of the real skills, the real toolkit . . . https://t.co/e2xkV4sYqg
RSS as an information security tool. https://t.co/LGumeNbLwQ
I am guessing that it is possible to set up a river of news site made up of social media posts from people witnessing and reporting a crisis anywhere in the world.
Phone report from Ukraine, brief thread. https://t.co/0pEY3NoBy8
Red Square, 2008, Paul McCartney rocks a live "Back in the U.S.S.R." for the crowd, but Putin is unmoved. https://t.co/Jo3N380j8G at 0:15. https://t.co/aNRS5ftHnv

After a beautiful concert, I accidentally insulted the pianist, saying the performance was lovely and so athletic. Disapproval flashed on her face as she repeated the word athletic. (In my defense: there had been some wiping of the brow.) The nearby violinist did not comment. https://t.co/srFJkjS1XB
I readily confess that I don’t know how to talk about classical music.
A thread from @TheRaDR about a richer understanding of what it means to heal, and a book to follow. https://t.co/MGpS7jRX82 https://t.co/gSUofC3kmT
Thirty degrees colder here in northern Indiana than at this same time yesterday. https://t.co/DkX3SVTS47

@TheRaDR I remember my daughter and her friend sitting at the table mocking their junior high health book because they plainly saw how terrified the book/the society was of human bodies. They saw the book twist slyly away from discussing what they cared about. They mocked and mocked it.
@TheRaDR They saw, on some level, that the society was in the process of abandoning them and betraying them.

"They introduced their most extreme measures gradually—strategically—in order to gauge how each new outrage was received.... The doses became progressively stronger until all Europe finally perished from them.” https://t.co/RGOyWc70pO
Behaving like a traitor, the former president enthuses about Putin’s strategy moves . . . https://t.co/vMYr05whpN
Lately I have heard photographers say it four different ways. You take a photograph, make a photograph, find a photograph, or let a photograph find you. https://t.co/S0fcxLSI1L

From @MonaEltahowy: Nina Simone evokes two kinds of awareness raised by music: 1. You must now see us and see our life circumstances. https://t.co/KCZI5wJkse 2. You must know that we see you and the part you’ve played in shaping our life circumstances. https://t.co/hdlylaZYAz
If you’d like to take a live, in-nest eagle cam break or just check the weather on the Indiana-Michigan border. https://t.co/AhSc4XuUrI https://t.co/XCQ8bRoDzg

"Eventually, even well-meaning journalists and intellectuals became guilty of what he called “the ‘doping’ of excitement”—an artificial incitement of emotion that culminated, inevitably, in mass hatred and fear." From "When It’s Too Late to Stop Fascism" https://t.co/RGOyWc70pO
